184018.name: Orléans: Neue Ortskarten N°2

184019.name: Rituals
184019.description:
A 3D puzzle-exploration-adventure about the relation between civilisation and nature.

You'll get lost in dark woods, try to escape erupting volcano and explore underground facilities.

At its core RITUALS is an adventure game but its environments and puzzles are designed to tell a story. Will you put it together?

Source: The Game Website.

184021.description:
Eve of the Sickle Moon is an expansion to the heroic adventure game Shadowrift, a cooperative deck-building game in which the players are heroes defending a town against a horde of monsters in a high-stakes fantasy siege. This expansion adds two new monster factions:

• The Lycanthrope faction consists of were-animals in many shapes and sizes. They all bear the common theme that they're able to bite villagers and spread their curse, and that when the full moon rises they become more powerful.

• The Harrowood faction is a forest that has been twisted into a violent hatred of humanity by the opening of the Shadowrifts. They can create Overgrowths, which empower their faction and speed the town's destruction.

To fight back against these foes, the heroes have four new hero cards with druidic power and four new hero cards with Elementalist powers. Three new villagers and a Wall are also included.
184021.name: Shadowrift: Eve of the Sickle Moon

184023.name: Thief & Policeman
184023.description: A wonderfull two player game. One player gets to be the thief and one the policeman. Each player moves and then places coloured pieces on the board, in order to block his opponent. When the policeman or the thief is completely blocked, the game ends!

184025.description:
As the active player you may reveal the next 4 cards at once in the discover phase. This grants you one additional purchase.
You must not fend off any ships, and taxes are dealt with in the revealed order. After that you are forced to end your discover phase.

Originally available as a door prize at Stadt Land Spielt, then later packaged with Spielbox 2016/1.
184025.name: Port Royal: Gambler Promo Card

184027.name: King Under the Mountain
184027.description:
You and your friends are Dwarf Lords leading an expedition to a remote mountain, rich in resources the Dwarf Kingdoms need. You each lead a group of Dwarven Miners and workers as they delve deep into the heart of the mountain. You goal is to establish a new, powerful and wealthy Dwarven kingdom and become King under the Mountain.

Each turn you will send your Dwarf Workers out to mine through the mountain, build buildings, craft jewelry, ingots, coins, and armor. You make all the decisions, no dice to determine what resources you receive. Do you mine that gold and mint coins to lure more dwarf workers to come to your banner? Or do you harvest gems to start building your hoard of jewelry?

Resources located in the tiles include:
Iron ore
Raw Gems
Gold Ore
Coal

Items which can be built as cards you hold include:
Steel ingots
Gold Ingots
Cut Gem Piles
Gold Coin Piles
Warrior Gear
Jewelry Piles.

These are produced in the following buildings which are placed onto the table as tiles, replacing caverns and mines:
Smelter
Jewelers shop
Smithy
Mint
Armory

But plan your realm layout carefully, at some point your delving will converge with those of your competitors. At that time the game changes and you will need Warriors to defend your fledgling realm. Or you may even decide to go on the attack denying the enemy their buildings and resources.

Through the building of a mighty military or a greed inspiring pile of jewelry you can become the King Under the Mountain.

184028.description: Abluxxen: Königskarten is a set of eight special Abluxxen cards and rule cards.
184028.name: Abluxxen: Königskarten

184029.name: Bola
184029.description: Bola has twelve double-sided cards, with each card showing a colored ball on each side. The balls come in eight colors, and each color appears three times. Each turn, one card is flipped to its opposite side, and whoever succeeds in finding three balls of the same color scores a point. Whoever first scores five points wins!

184030.description:
With this card, your everyday stress is as owner of a fast food restaurant becomes more realistic. It was missing a crucial element: The Difficult Customer

1 Card + 1 Rule Card
184030.name: Speed Snacks: The Difficult Customer Promo Card

184032.name: Red Bit Ninja
184032.description:
User Summary

This is a retro-styled platformer that prides itself on difficulty and having players jump into the unknown (and usually die). Its main innovation is a chain rope that the character shoots out while jumping which the character can climb to upper levels. To detach from the chain rope, the character jumps away. There are 5 bosses and sixty levels.

184033.name: Conflict: Writer's and GM Screen
184033.description:
Publisher Blurb:

This beautiful 4-panel screen features magnificent art by Rafael Dorsz on the outer panels and on the inside you will find hundreds of inspirational examples of ways you can describe characters in intense fantasy combat. Strategically organized by the type of damage the character wishes to inflict and the fighting style the character is performing. The types of damage include: Blunt (damage caused by non-penetrating force), Slashing (damage caused by a sharp edge) and Piercing (damage caused by a sharp point). The combat styles include: Finesse (a character who fights with style and grace, such as the Swashbuckler or Martial Artist), Power (a character whose fight is based on strength and vigor, such as the Barbarian or Thug) and Range (a character who is using a thrown or distance weapon such as a javelin or bow). Plus additional descriptions from the Conflict: Storyteller's Deck (Ill Intent, Expressions, Character Distinctions, Environment) so improve your combat narrative and storytelling at a glance! Conflict: Writers and GM Screen is System Neutral.

184034.name: Conflict: Storyteller's Deck
184034.description:
Publisher Blurb:

This 80-card deck is filled with inspiring ways to describe the delicate nuances of your world. Each card contains action words to spark the imagination, followed by multiple examples of their use. The perfect addition to spice up any players' experience! Broken up into 6 individual sets, each set is separately illustrated by Rafael Dorsz and printed on large 4.25" x 2.75" (Tarot-sized) cards.

184035.description:
Publisher Blurb:

100 page score pad for Deck Building: The Deck Building Game.
boardgameaccessory: Deck Building: The Deck Building Game
boardgamepublisher: Greater Than Games (Dice Hate Me Games)
184035.name: Deck Building: The Deck Building Game – Score Pad

184036.description:
Publisher Blurb:

A punchboard blue noodle with a plastic base for use with Unpub: The Unpublished Card Game. Use it to mark the active publisher.
boardgamepublisher: Greater Than Games (Dice Hate Me Games)
184036.name: Unpub: The Unpublished Card Game – Blue Noodle

184037.name: Dice Of Debt
boardgamepodcastepisode: I've Been Diced! episode 70: John Kranz of Consimworld
184037.description:
Dice Of Debt is a "serious game" designed to help software development teams deal with the common problem of technical debt. If you're not familiar with the concept, technical debt is the drag on productivity that sloppy coding and testing create. Teams sometimes have to take shortcuts, but they pay the price, in the long term. Here's where to get it: http://www.game-change-llc.com/diceofdebt/

Teams often have a hard time justifying to their management, or to themselves, the investment needed to reduce technical debt. Fixing the existing code, or implementing practices that improve the quality of future code, have a cost. Under time pressures, and with an unclear picture of how much of a drag on productivity technical debt really is, teams are hesitant to make a hard choice, even if it increases the amount of software value that the team will eventually deliver.

The game simulates the work of an Agile software team over the course of 10 sprints. (If you're not familiar with Agile, or sprints, just suffice it to say that we're talking about the work that a team can get done in a series of 10 2-week intervals.) The 12 dice used in the game represent the team's capacity, which is split between coding new features and dealing with the burden of technical debt. You roll one set of dice to represent the value of the new features, then subtract the total from the roll of another set of dice to represent the burden of technical debt.

The players (working cooperatively, since they're the team) can decide to implement measures that will reduce technical debt. Either the pool of technical debt dice will get smaller, or you will subtract from the final result of rolling these dice. You have to set aside some time and effort to implement these technical debt-reducing measures, so your capacity for coding new features will drop temporarily.

The goal of the game is to produce the largest amount of new software value (features) by the end of the game (again, 10 turns, representing "sprints"). There's no specific "win" condition, other than to see how much better you can do, in the end, than if you had taken no action to reduce technical debt.

The real victory the players can achieve is a good conversation about what they might do, in their own work on software teams, to reduce technical debt. Now that they've seen the long-term productivity gain they can achieve from a short-term productivity loss, it will become easier to justify the difficult choices.

The game is not designed to provide an extremely accurate simulation of the benefits that each technical debt-reducing measure might provide. However, it does simulate other aspects of decision-making about technical debt. For example, the players can see how important it is to invest earlier rather than later in reducing technical debt. In these ways, the game also provides simulation value.

Dice Of Debt is going to be part of a package of materials that the Agile Alliance is producing to help people combat technical debt. We will post more specifics when we have them. The current plan is to publish this package by the end of 2015.

184038.description:
From the publisher:

PAX Expansion: the slaves are re-arming themselves and Rome, too, does not remain idle. With the new cards; Militia, Scouts, and Adversaries, additional tactics are possible for the slaves as well as for Rome.

Pergamemnon Expansion: out of the Abyss come the Germans and the Macedonians, two more powerful nations to compete with the others. In addition to the specific skills of each people, all players now have the option to acquire additional skills.
184038.name: PAX & Pergamemnon Expansions

184039.description:
Publisher Blurb:

Beautiful standard sized play mat, made of a high quality mouse pad-like material, 24.25" X 14.25
184039.name: Barbarossa: Playmat

184040.name: Monster Math Munch
184040.description: Monster Math Munch is an educational math game for children in grades 4 to 6. Each player places their game piece on the start of their own track. The first player chooses a card an reads the math problem on the card to the player to their left. If that player answers correctly he or she moves one space forward. Play continues to the left until one player reaches the end space of the track, winning the game.

184041.description:
Publisher Blurb:

Hordes dice set for Skorne faction, produced together with Privateer Press. The only one original!
184041.name: Hordes: Skorne Dice

184042.description:
Res Publica: 2230AD is expanded through the New Horizons. 5 new planets with different missions in order to increase the replay-ability of the game.

Stradus II: An earth-like planet with an unusually large axial tilt causing extreme seasonal changes. Both the northern and southern hemispheres experience harsh winters, with cold nights that can last for weeks or months at a time depending on latitude.

Loorte: A habitable planet with a pleasant climate, homeworld of the Loort species. The Loorts are a friendly species with a simple agrarian society and limited scientific knowledge. While they are not capable of spaceflight (and seem to have no interest in leaving their world) they nevertheless interact with other species.

Khone: A large terrestrial planet with high gravity. The curious thing about this planet is that life has evolved on a miniature scale.

Cenai: An extremely hot planet with high levels of CO2, sulphur dioxide, and carbon monoxide in the atmosphere. The planet was probably once like earth, but runaway global warming has turned it into a barren wasteland.

Alura Prime: An earth-like planet with a breathable atmosphere. One large continent stretches from the north pole to the south pole, dividing the planet's large ocean in two. The super-continent is home to a species of intelligent but primitive frog-like creatures.
184042.name: Res Publica: 2230AD – New Horizons

184043.name: Reversi (Windows/Macintosh/Linux)
184043.description:
User Summary

This the fullest implementation to date of this classic board game, Reversi. Now although it follows the Othello rule set (start up placement alternated and a passed turn results when out of legal moves -- which came as quite a surprise) the games are so similar I think it's perfectly fine to use the older generic name for the game. You can play locally, online, or against a good computer AI. The camera can be moved around, there is asynchronous play available, a leaderboard -- basically a lot of features to tailor the game to your liking. Although the game had its fair share of bugs when it first came out, that seems to be in the past. This game is made by the same BGGers (BlueLine Games) who brought out the wonderful versions of Khet and Hive.

184044.description:
In Cul-De-Sac Conquest players compete to annoy each other out of their neighborhood.

Everyone plays an annoying neighbor who can aggravate their neighbors with loud barking dogs or persistent Christmas carolers, they can relax their own characters by meditating or watching TV in bed, they can upgrade their houses with hot tubs or game rooms and sometimes accidentally annoy themselves by stubbing their toe or getting a parking ticket.

Once a character reaches their rage meter they are out of the game.
184044.name: Cul-De-Sac Conquest
boardgamepodcastepisode: Episode 20 - Andrew Birkett of Atheris Games

184045.name: Bubble Guppies Fin-tastic Field Trip Game
184045.description:
From the box:
"8 place to visit, 4 games to play! Use the 4 double-sided game boards individually to play a fast-placed, token-collecting game. OR, put them together to make your very own game board and the race begins! Collect tokens from each area and be the first one home, to win."

Bubble Guppies Fin-Tastic Field Trip Game is a spin-and-move game where players move their characters around the track, collecting tokens. The board is modular and may be reassembled in different configurations. Each section represents a particular location, such as a museum, farm or supermarket. The object of the game is to visit each location and collect a token from each before returning to the starting space. To make the game more challenging, tokens can be placed face-down to add a memory element.

There are also three other versions to play the game included. In Gil's Game, players must claim tokens held up by a game leader by matching them to pictures on their board. The first player to fill his or her board wins. Molly's Memory Game is a re-theme of the classic matching game Memory. In Mr. Grouper's What's Missing? Game, players take turns playing the role of Mr. Grouper. Mr. Grouper lays out five tiles. After looking at them, other players close their eyes and Mr. Grouper removes one tile. Players in turn try to identify the missing tile. The first player to identify the tile wins it. The next player to the left then becomes Mr. Grouper. The player with the most tiles at the end of the game wins.

184046.description: A picture of an actual Titan II Missile Base control panel, taken at the Titan Missile Base Museum, printed on cardstock.
184046.name: Nuclear War: Playmat

184047.name: Brainy Quiz Contest
184047.description: Brainy Quiz Contest is a trivia game for children, published in India. Each player has a token which they move along a track. On each space, they spin a spinner to choose a trivia question category. Then the quiz master chooses a card and asks them a multiple-choice question in the category chosen. If the answer is wrong, the player must choose a "punishment" card requiring them to do some sort of stunt. If the answer is correct, the player moves forward and answers another question, continuing until a wrong answer is given. The first player to reach the end of the track wins, gaining the winner's crown and prize check.

184048.name: The Tolling of the Great Black Bell (Issue 6 - Aug 2015)
rpgissue: The Tolling of the Great Black Bell
184048.description:
The Tolling of the Great Black Bell
Fanzine focusing on AD&D 2nd Ed.
Issue 6 - August 2015

184049.name: Behind Enemy Lines (2005 Edition)
184049.description:
(From the back Cover)

Crack parachutists decend out of the night. Their target: the bridge vital to the sucess of a spearhead allied attack only hours away. The bridge is wired and mined for detonation and
intelligence reports suggest that an SS Panzer Division is in the area. As the paratroops gather in their chutes, ready their gear, and form up their attack, they know that split-second timing and speed are their only chances for success...

Elite Rangers check their weapons and grapples and eye the cliff that rises from the beach into the pre-dawn mists. Their mission: hit the German battery at the top and hit it hard, before the Allied invasion fleet comes into range. A mortar blast geysers water beside the boat and someone cracks a lame joke about the welcome mat being out. Raw guts and determination are the only hope now...

A combat infantry squad peers from the cover of scattered trees and boulders along the crest of a ridge at the river below. Their problem: the last bridge over the last river between them and friendly lines lies below and the intelligence they have gathered about Panzers in the area must be returned to HQ, and fast. There is a slight complication: a Tiger I tank squatting by the road on the near bank. Only daring and inqenuity can get them back from...

BEHIND ENEMY LINES

Behind Enemy Lines is a role-playing game which allows you to take on the character of a U.S. Infantryman in World War II. Parachute drops, night raids, sniper ambushes, pitched battles,
combat patrols, and long-range reconnaissance probes are the challanges you face. Your enemy is cunning, well-trained and well-equipped. Your ingenuity, your courage, and skill are
all that stand between you and disaster.

184050.name: Calculodingo
184050.description:
CalculoDingo is a goldmine that will accompany your children or students (particularly teachers' aides) in kindergarten and older

The game CalculoDingo offers 15 different rules with the same set of cards. These rules allow to practice counting, additions, subtractions and doubling.
In CalculoDingo you will find the concepts in counting: recognize numbers, compare numbers, insert one number between two others, make sequences of numbers, parity, the decimal system (units and tens).

184051.name: Vocadingo
184051.description:
4 aliens disembark from their spaceship to study our language.

Gameplay: 200 words with their definitions, anagrams and riddles.

Give the right answers and win the most of vocabulary words.

A comical game to enrich the vocabulary of kindergardeners all the way to adults!

184052.name: FractoDingo
184052.description:
A fun game to learn about fractions!. Master representations of fractions and their additions.
A playful tool organised into 3 levels of difficulty.
Play the battle, Rummy and the Mistigri to help pirates to share their treasure.

184053.name: Synodingo
184053.description:
Ideal for CE1 and CE2, here are 5 rules different games (Battle,
Rummy, Mistigri, SpeedoSyno and DevineMoi) to learn 200 words.

Each word, in addition to its definition, has a synonym and two antonyms.
For example: friend → ally, foe, opponent.
A fun tool that increases in difficulty, to enrich the vocabulary for second graders onward.

184054.name: Vocadingo: CM1 CM2
184054.description:
Following the great success of Vocadingo for kindergardeners, here is a new comical game to enrich vocabulary children 9 and over.
Four aquatic heroes arrive to study our language.
Gameplay: 200 words each with its definition, its anagram and its riddle!

Give the right answers and win the most vocabulary cards!

184055.name: Sonodingo
184055.description:
Learn Phonics from a playful perspective!
Consisting of 102 maps words, Sonodingo is a scalable game with 5 different levels. For each level, there is, for each card, a card that begins with the same syllable and a card that ends up the same syllable.
Simple and traditional games as mistigri, Rummy, the battle... give a touch of fun to approach the phonology.
Important step in the establishment of phonological awareness, and the process of learning to read, Sonodingo can be used from the large section of kindergarten for learning of phonetic syllables. In CP/CE1, we can also use the spelling of the words corresponding to the phonetic syllables to make understand the existence of different spellings for a phonetic syllable.
A clever system of verification helps children to correct themselves. Parents and teachers will also appreciate the beautiful illustrations and the affordable price of Sonodingo.

184056.name: Sylladingo
184056.description:
Two inspectors must rebuild 700 vocabulary words from 96 letters and syllables.

Play the battle, Rummy and the Caterpillar to help reconstruct the words.

Sylladingo is a fun tool to enrich the vocabulary of the CP to the CM1. The game includes 2 packs of different cards (easy and hard levels).

184057.name: Conjudingo CE1
184057.description:
Conjudingo includes 3 easy and fun games to practice the present, future simple and past compound tenses with kids the CE1 to the CM1.

The different animals on the cards help you verify whether the combination is correct

Conjudingo is the practical and comical tool for all conjugations in the CE1 program.

184058.name: Conjudingo CE2
184058.description:
Conjudingo CE2 includes 3 games easy and fun to work the verbs of the 2nd and 3rd groups present, future and imperfect (auxiliary, 1st, 2nd and 3rd groups) with the children of CE2 in the CM1. The different animals on the maps help you verify whether the combination is good.

Conjudingo is the practical and playful tool for all conjugations of the elementary school curriculum.

184059.name: Motdingo
184059.description:
Have fun building words using syllables categorized by frequency they are used in the French language. Play 4 different minigames including 'Top list' that allows players of all ages to play together and to use texts as a resource.
A fun way to enhance writing and vocabulary of the CP to CM2 students (grades 1 and 2, roughly)!

184060.name: Ad Astra:  The New Age
184060.description:
User Summary:

Ad Astra: The New Age was last updated in 2004. The game system is published as a series of HTML pages, with these major sections: Campaign Section; Character Generation; Combat Section; Level Advancement; and How Dice Work in Ad Astra. This web page is freely accessible to the public.

The rules presented on the HTML page are very lightweight, emphasizing roleplay over mechanics.

184061.name: ARM: Advanced Role-Playing Mechanics
184061.description:
From the introduction:

ARM is an adaptable generic RPG, designed by a minimalist author. This means that details are often left up to the GM and the players - I prefer that room for my imagination to work, and I dislike getting bogged down in complex rules.

User summary:

ARM uses a unique logarithmic resolution table to determine target difficulty. Character stats are also based on logarithmic values adjusted by situational modifiers and a die roll. This resolution process is used for everything in the game. The game is copyright but distributed freely and exists in ASCII text form only.

184062.name: Aisling Book 1: Revelation
184062.description:
Aisling: Where Dreams Run Free
Book 1 - Revelation

User summary:

Book one consists of setting information as well as an overview of the major tribes, rades, realms, and types of magic available. Major sections include: The World of Aisling; The Tell; The Plasm; The Caesura; Noom (The Tribes; The Rades); Realms; and Magic.

The setting is very atypical and unique. Characters exist in a sort of dual-phase reality where they transcend the normal world and move into a magical world where they can adventure.

184063.name: Aisling Book 2: Choice
184063.description:
Aisling: Where Dreams Run Free
Book 2 - Choice

User summary:

Book two consists of character information and presents the system's conflict resolution process. Major sections include: Characters (Concepts, Creation, Building); In Depth (Thresholds, Traits, Aspects); Chance (The Spectrum, The Draw, Tagging, Mastery); Conflict (Weapons, Damage, Healing); Magic (Schools, The Arts, Feits, Raptures, Chants, Charms); Luck; and Change.

Character creation can follow one of several paths and may be quite simple but may also be very complex, depending on the path selected and the desired character. The conflict resolution process is quite unique and is used to handle all opposed actions, of any sort, in the game.

184064.name: Aisling Book 3: Transformation
184064.description:
Aisling: Where Dreams Run Free
Book 3 - Transformation

User summary:

Book three consists of thematic elements and campaign strategies. Major sections include: Playing the Character; Improvisation; Bringing Them Together; Themes & Motifs; NPCs; Climactic Scenes; and Running the Game.

While most of the information presented here is typical of any RPG, there are notable exceptions due to the unique nature of the game's setting and conflict resolution system.

184065.name: Aisling Appendices
184065.description:
Aisling: Where Dreams Run Free
Appendices

User summary:

The appendices section consists of random topics or supporting materials that do not fit into one of the three major "books" of the core system.

Entries include: Glossary; Inspiring Works; Non-human Player Characters; Noom; Creatures; Characters; Making Motes; Motecards; Dicing Aisling; Charts and Tables; Design Philosophy; and Probabilities. Note that as-of the last site update (2009) some of these entries are blank. The appendices also include several "working" pages which are noted as being temporary and optional.

184067.name: ERA:  Storyteller Resource
184067.description:
User Summary:

Storyteller Resource contains information on:
- hacking ERA for other settings
- strategies for populating adventures with monsters
- monster creation
- example bestiary

184068.name: Mephisto (Issue 54 - May/Jun 2012)
184068.description: Apart from news and reviews, issue #54 has interviews with writer Maike Hallmann and Oliver Graute, an article on literary awards for German fantasy, a new Arkham Horror Scenario, scenarios, locations, and other material for several RPGs.

184070.name: Mephisto (Issue 21 - Nov/Dec 2002)
184070.description: Issue 21 contains news, reviews, articles, an interview with and short story by cyberpunk writer John Shirley, and gaming material for half a dozen systems.

184071.description:
Collect the ladybugs and katydids while avoiding stink bugs and other destructive bugs

The game play mechanics are simple. It's a collecting game that involves 52 cards of mostly insects and other creatures of the yard. What makes this game unique and different from your average trick taking game is that you don't just add your points up when all cards have been played. There's a damage phase that takes place when scoring and certain cards (or bugs) will eat other bugs. There are many different combinations of scoring that can happen depending on what you collect.
184071.name: Backyard Bugs

184072.description:
Flying Saucers Junior is simpler version of the game Flying Saucers. It has less fields on the board and only first level of Flying Saucers, with less figurines.

Figurines represent different categories of flying saucers, which differ in speed, size and power. Flying saucers destroy enemy saucers by stopping next to it. Flying saucer with more power, or joined multiple saucers can destroy enemy flying saucer. The goal of the game is to destroy the main enemy flying saucer.

The game can be played with dice or without it.
184072.name: Flying Saucers Junior

184073.name: The Cursed Forest
184073.description:
UNRELEASED GAME – AVAILABLE




This game is still either in Early-Alpha or Beta (or any status in between) but IS already available for sale / early access, so CAN BE PLAYED.




User Summary

Walk through an autumnal forest. As you travel uncover the dark story behind the place.

184074.name: MANOS: The Hands of Fate Director's Cut
184074.description: NES style platformer based on the movie Manos The Hands of Fate but also pays homage to other terrible video games and movies.

184075.description: One Night Ultimate Werewolf: Bonus Pack 2 consists of four new roles, two new artifacts, and two alternative artwork cards for use with One Night Ultimate Werewolf, One Night Ultimate Werewolf Daybreak, and One Night Ultimate Vampire.
184075.name: One Night Ultimate Werewolf: Bonus Pack 2

184076.name: Big Pharma
184076.description:
As the head of your own Pharmaceutical Conglomerate you have this power resting in your hands. Will you use it for good? Being totally altruistic may not be the best business plan. The uncomfortable truth (is there an ointment for that?) is that some remedies are more profitable than others and illness is good for business.

Welcome to the world of Big Pharma! ...

Big Pharma is part business sim, part logistics puzzle. It’s one thing to work away in the lab perfecting new formulas, but converting the ‘sciency stuff’ into cold hard cash means bringing an engineering and business mind to the problem.

Factory space is expensive, and those fancy new agglomerators and centrifuges don’t always slot nicely together.

Source: The Game Website.

184077.name: Tables and Chairs
184077.description:
Stack high to win, stack wide to win, just don't let the stack of furniture fall!

The game is hanging in the balance...think you can stack one more table or one more chair without toppling the pile? Then grab a piece of furniture, and get ready to play! Players take turns stacking tables or chairs any way they can, until one of them topples the pile all over! Be careful because the entire game is a balancing act! The player with the fewest toppled furnishings at the end of the game is the winner or if you'd rather, be the one to finish stacking all your furnishings first!

Some may know the game Chairs... this is incredibly similar except you have both tables and chairs, not just chairs to work with! This variation of the game "Chairs" provides new surfaces & chair shapes to stack and balance. Think you can balance that round table on the square chair with holes in it? How about putting that 3-legged chair upside down on a short long coffee table piece.

Game comes with 3 different color tables and chairs of varying shapes and sizes. Add a new play element to your game night with the game, "Tables and Chairs"!

184078.name: Awkward Family Photos Card Game
184078.description:
This hilarious card game combines creative, open-ended questions with all new cringeworthy photos featuring funny family portraits, unfortunate hairstyles, weddings, vacations and holidays throughout the year!

Your ridiculous answers guarantee memorable & awkward fun...and if you know your fellow players well enough and can impress them with your answers, you'll get the last laugh!

Game is completely customizable in regards to rules changes, additions, etc. For example, you could add a couple dice to randomize your question number, rather than "learning the questions and choosing favorites". Really, this open game allows for house rules and so forth. The options are endless and the game can be altered based on your groups play-style.

Note* Dice and 'extras' do not come in this game, they are simply suggestions.




Before the game begins, determine what 'score' you're playing to. Might be 5, might be 10, might be 34! It's up to the group to determine how long they plan to play. (See below, how to win)

On your turn, draw a photo card and choose a number (or roll a die, if thats your thing, completely up to you!). That number correlates to a question to be answered about the photo selected. Maybe you have to come up with a caption for the photo or maybe you decide what the portrait is thinking. Format similar to Cards Against Humanity, best answer wins picture card which equals 1 point. Or maybe you want to play by coming up with alternative answers and the group determines who said what best. Winner of that round keeps picture card and scores a point. First person to win "X" number of cards is the winner.

184079.description:
GO MONSTERS!

Go Monsters! is a card/board game that uses the card mechanics of Go Fish but adds board game mechanics of grid movement, tactics decisions, strategic planning, along with smashing buildings and victory points.

Age: Above 5
Number of Players: 2 to 4
Game Time: 20 to 30 min

Components:
[52 cards] - on [6] 8.5x11 single sided PDF sheets - Monster Cards "Equal to a regular deck of cards"
[1] - 8.5 x 11 Double sided PDF sheet - Game boards
[4] - d6 dice [2 white - 2 yellow]
[16] - building counters - "or you can use cubes, dice, tokens"
[4] – Individually colored Monster figurers with base – [red, green, blue, and yellow]
[1] rule book
184079.name: Go Monsters!
boardgamefamily: Children's Game Print and Play Contest

184080.description:
You count yourself amongst the best murderers in Victorian England. You must dispatch of your opponents one-by-one using various methods of villainy and vileness, but, be careful, for your fellow compatriots of evil deeds also want you dead and The All Seeing Eye of the Law diligently looks into the ominous shadows of the night.

During game play, players play action cards from their hand in which they may either do the action on the card or sometimes attempt murder on their fellow players by rolling the die.
184080.name: Polite Murder

184082.description: Superhero Ko! is a simultaneous action two, four, or six player game packed with Golden Era Comic Book Superheros. Duel your fellow players in dice rolling matches to win XP. Who will be the first to KO! another player and become the hero the people need?
184082.name: Superhero KO!

184083.description:
In Take Out the Trash, you must decided whether to Trash, Recycle, or Reuse. And, sometimes you find a dead cat or even a dead man. This card game is a fast paced trick taking game where the person who takes out the trash the best wins.

In this trick taking games, players are dealt a hand with which they must bid on the left over cards. The winning bidder declares a trump and the play begins. Players may also attack each other with Do Not Trash cards and the player with the most points on won tricks wins the match.
184083.name: Take Out the Trash

184084.name: Anarcha Australis
184084.description:
From the rules:

Anarcha Australis is set in Australia...around 2020. After the Total Economic Collapse...[of] 1993...Australia turned into a total anarchy. Looting and other crimes turned rife as the prices on commercial products skyrocketed; the government attempted to bring back economic order by re-evaluating the economy, and released the $500 coin. However, it was too late; the entire country collapsed. In the next five years, crime, disease and famine ruled as families attempted to survive in the total chaos of post-economic collapse. The government, after its initial attempts of stabilisation, faded away.

User summary:

Released only as an ASCII text file. The core rules are minimal but nearly complete. The game often is referred to online as Anarcho Australis (with an "-o") but the rules consistently use Anarcha Australis.

184085.description:
A dead body has been found on board a ship, and all passengers seem to have an alibi. Luckily several professionals are on board willing to help, but can you trust them? By asking clever questions and using deductive reasoning, you just might manage to expose the missing alibi and identify the murderer.

Perfect Alibi is a classic deduction game in the tradition of Sleuth. However, Perfect Alibi has a shorter playing time, and unlike other deduction games some of the information you get might be false. Finding out who is lying to whom is therefore crucial, and you must take full advantage of the abilities of several available assistants to gain the information you need.
184085.name: Perfect Alibi
boardgamepodcastepisode: clp009 – cubelove podcast – Internationale Spieltage SPIEL’15 Essen

184086.name: Anarchy Role-Playing System Storybook
184086.description:
User summary:

The storybook, released as HTML and ASCII text, provides the setting for the game. It has a concise history, an enumeration of planets (with brief descriptions), and list of major intelligent species. Earth, Venus, and Mars are more developed than the other planets. Sections on vehicles, money, making items, and scientific advances complete the document.

184087.name: Anarchy Role-Playing System Technical Manual
184087.description:
User summary:

The technical manual, released as HTML and ASCII text, provides instructions on how to build characters (using the supplied character sheet), enemies (using the supplied enemy sheet), and new weapon types (using the supplied weapon sheet). It also provides the core mechanic of the game, in which any contested action is resolved with a dice pool roll against a target difficulty. If the action is contested by another person then the target difficult will be the opponent's dice pool, otherwise the GM will assign a difficulty.

Interestingly, the rules also include mechanics for "winning" the game, which the GM does if all the players are killed!

The document is supported by three single-page supplementary sheets, as noted above.

184088.name: Microsoft Solitaire Collection
184088.description:
Check out the new look and feel of Microsoft Solitaire Collection on Windows 10!

Solitaire remains the most played computer game of all time, and for good reason. Simple rules and straightforward gameplay make it easy to pick up for everyone.

Solitaire has been part of Windows for more than 25 years, and the Microsoft Solitaire Collection makes it the best experience to date with five different card games in one:

Klondike This version is the timeless classic that many people just call "Solitaire." Try to clear all the cards from the table using one or three-card draw, while using traditional scoring or the Vegas scoring system.

Spider Eight columns of cards await your attempts to clear them with the fewest moves possible. Start out playing with a single suit until you’re comfortable, and then see how you fare when using two or even all four suits in a game.

FreeCell Use four extra cells to move cards around as you try to clear all cards from the table. More strategic than the Klondike version, FreeCell rewards players who think several moves ahead.

TriPeaks Select cards in a sequence, either up or down, to earn points and clear the board. How many boards can you clear before you run out of deals?

Pyramid Pair two cards that add up to 13 in order to remove them from the board. Try to reach the top of the pyramid. See how many boards you can clear and how high you can score in this highly addictive card game!

Daily Challenges Players receive new challenges each day. Complete enough Daily Challenges in a month to earn badges and compete with your friends.

Star Club Even more challenges arranged in collections and packs you can unlock by earning stars.

Choose Your Theme The Microsoft Solitaire Collection features several beautiful themes, from the simplicity of "Classic" to the serenity of an Aquarium that comes to life before you while you play. You can even create custom themes from your own photos!

Xbox Live Integration Sign in with your Microsoft account to earn achievements, compete with your friends on the leaderboards, and track your personal gameplay statistics. If you sign in with a Microsoft account, your progress is stored in the cloud so you can play the game on any device without missing a beat!

Source: The Developer Website.

184089.name: Angel/Demon: Dancing the Spheres
184089.description:
From the supplement:

Welcome to Dancing the Spheres, a source supplement to Angel/Demon: The Rapture, a public domain storyteller game. For those of you who have read the main rules, this supplement does not contain any rule additions or subtractions. This is merely a discussion on the nature and habitat of the Cherubim/Belial race, something that was intentionally left out of the main rules document. Hopefully this supplement will clear the air of any questions you, as a player or storyteller, might have about the angels.

184090.name: Build Me Up!
184090.description:
Build me up! The Self-Esteem Game is a roll-and-move board game where players attempt to earn money by praising other players and building their self-esteem. Players roll a die to move on a track, landing on various letters along the way. When they land on a letter, they must use three (or four or five, depending on the level chosen) positive words describing the player to their left or right in sentences, within 30 seconds. If they are able to do so, they earn an amount of money that corresponds to the difficulty of the letter (for example Y and U earn $1000, A and S earn $300). One player is The Negotiator, a sort of gamemaster. Players who are unable to think of enough words can buy a word from the negotiator (who has a book of suggested words) for half the value of the letter space. The Negotiator also controls the money and the timer.

Players may not repeat words that have already been used. Other players may challenge a word used by a player as being incorrect or not positive. If the challenge is successful, the challenger gets double the value of the letter. If the challenge fails, the original player gets double value. The rules specify that a dictionary should be consulted by the Negotiator. There are also "self-esteem" space where players draw a card which describes an effect of high or low self-esteem. These cards either give extra money to the player or cause a penalty to be paid. If a player must pay a penalty and has too little money, he or she must get a loan from The Negotiator, which must be paid back plus 10% interest.

Game play continues for 30 minutes. At the end of the game, the player with the most money wins, and is awarded a Certificate of Merit.

184091.name: Anime RPG
184091.description:
User summary:

The Anime RPG attempts to provide a tabletop framework upon which any style of anime roleplaying may be accomplished. The game plays in two major modes - story mode and action mode; story mode is narrative and is interrupted only when some critical opposed action must be resolved. Action mode proceeds in rounds and uses exploding dice for resolution. In addition to target success numbers, the GM may assign situational die bonus or penalties.

The game itself is presented as five major HTML pages: Introduction (concise), Gameflow, Actions, Abilities, and Experience.

184092.name: CARPS - Customizable Abstract Roleplaying System Version 4.0
184092.description:
From the Introduction:

Well, here it is; version 4.0 of CARPS. In the making of this, I trashed every single rule. This is a completely different game system than 3.5. I think you will find it quite drool-worthy. A lot of the rules seem kind of crazy and pointless, but they are all there for a damn good reason; don't question the RPG designer! At the bottom of the page I have added a justification for every rule. Finally, this is not for beginners. This is pretty advanced and makes no attempt to explain the basics of roleplaying. Newcomers would be better off with Version 3.5 or CARPS lite.

184093.name: Quick Draw Card Game
184093.description:
Quick Draw is a card came designed for 2-4 players whereby each player takes on the role of a Gunfighter in the old west. Each player begins the game with 30 life points, you can use glass beads or pen and paper to keep track of the life points. You will need a standard pack of cards that have 2 jokers, and around 10-15 six sided dice (less depending on number of players).

The game is divided into turns with each turn being made up of 3 rounds; Quick Draw, Aim and Fire. At the start of a turn the players are dealt 10 cards and then 5 communal cards are played face up in the middle of the play area.

For each round the players must use three cards from their hand to make the best poker hand they can. They place each round of cards face down in front of them (3 stacks of 3 cards). The left stack are the cards used for the Quick Draw round, the middle stack is used for the Aim Round and the Right Stack is used for the Fire Round. The last remaining card is placed to the very right of the Fire Stack.

When all of the players have made their selection all of the stacks of cards and the remaining card are turned over, spread out and revealed for all to see, then each player places 2d6 on top of their remaining card.

Starting with the Quick Draw Round, the poker hands are compared, players call out their best hand in turn giving the other players the opportunity to challenge their call. Once all hands have been called, the highest scoring player performs the action from the table below using the quick draw column and cross referencing it with his poker hand, once his action has been completed the next highest highest player performs their action in the same way, this continues until all player have taken an action.

Play moves to the Aim round which is repeated exactly as with the quick draw round and then the Fire round is performed.

When the dice are rolled in the Fire Round, their result is deducted directly from the player to the left or right of the active player who may choose either one. If a player ends with a negative results, then they take the damage themselves. When instructed to add or deduct dice in the fire round, just add or deduct the dice as directed to or from the remaining card of the player.

184094.name: Appleseed D6
184094.description:
From the web page:

This...role-playing game is set in the world of Masamune Shirow's classic cyberpunk series Appleseed.

User summary:

The game mechanic is derived from the d6 System by West End Games. Freely available, the system is well-developed and complete. The rules are presented as a series of HTML pages, including:

- Welcome to Olympus
- The State of the World
- Game Mechanics (Dice, Boosts, Difficulties, Chi, Effect Value)
- Characters (Templates, Types, Attributes, Advantages, Details, Skills, Chi, Advancement)
- Attributes & Skills (Strength, Dexterity, Constitution, Knowledge, Instincts, Presence)
- Actions & Combat (Actions, Scale, Combat, Ranged Combat, Modifiers, Damage, Armor, Healing)
- Cybernetics (Limbs, Optics, Audio, Internals, Interface, Full-body, Catalog)
- Equipment (Weapons, Armor, Misc, Vehicles, Landmates)
- Appendices

184096.name: Archeus Fantasy Roleplaying Rules
184096.description:
User summary:

Archeus Fantasy Roleplaying was distributed under a GNU Free Documentation License. The design goal was a simple system that could handle virtually any roleplaying situation, though the system is a generic fantasy setting. A secondary goal was to ensure that "the bad guys" would always be balanced with "the good buys" (player characters), even as either group advanced in power level.

User summary:

The 0.3.1 version of the system was released in 2001 and has not been updated. The game presents a fairly robust and flexible method for character creation. Characters have "primary" and "secondary" stats, which are derived from primary stats. Any number of secondary skills may be created to support any needed action; skills may have active or passive uses. All opposed actions are resolved by using a lengthy "statistics bonuses" table to modify a statistic which is then compared to a percentile dice roll to determine success or failure.

The hosting site presented a series of online forms that users could access to submit new gaming materials such as skills, monsters, weapons, spells, and equipment which would then be incorporated into the rules.

184097.name: Dino Hunt Game
184097.description: Dino Hunt Game is a dinosaur-themed roll-and move game that comes packaged with a book and toy in Smart Kids Dino IQ by Priddy Books. Players roll a die to move their markers along a track. Some spaces move players forward or back or cause loss or gain of a turn. These spaces generally refer to a dinosaur, such as "Rammed by triceratops' horns--lose a turn." The first player to reach the end of the track wins.

184098.name: Cradle
184098.description:
User Summary

Cradle has you explore the surrounding world. The story is built around the relations of the protagonist and a mechanical girl.

184099.name: TIMEframe
184099.description:
User Summary

Time is relative and 10 seconds may feel like an eternity. You will discover a world in slow motion and see the remnants of a civilization on the brink of destruction.

184100.name: Dreaming
184100.description:
User Summary

Dreaming is a minimalist story about a man's journey through his dreams as he tries to find a girl who calls to him.

184101.name: Cylne
184101.description:
User Summary

Cylne is an exploration game in the form of a visual poems. Choose a chapter to explore environmental enigmas.

184102.name: Ardent Offense
184102.description:
User summary:

Ardent Offense was distributed as an HTML and a PDF file, copyrighted but made freely available. The game is set in a post-apocalyptic world where the laws and governance have broken down and individual power centers vie for control of resources. The rules are minimal and utilize a percentile system of skills modified by difficulty as a target against which percentile dice are rolled.

The core rules consist of a basic system of attributes, inferred skills, and opposed action resolution. Most of the documentation is given over to the philosophy of design and general concepts in roleplaying games.

184103.description: You can now buy a BLANK DECK of Nuclear War cards. This is a deck of 56 cards, with the backs the same as all the other Nuclear War cards, but the faces completely blank. Make up your own secrets. Add odd-sized warheads. Replace missing cards. Confuse your friends.
184103.name: Nuclear War: Blank Deck

184104.name: ARG: The Adventure Role Play Gaming System
rpg: ARG: The Adventure Role Play Gaming System
184104.description:
From the introduction:

The world had belonged to them once. The Gobolyns, Boggarts and Spriggans; the Trows, Trolls and Angorym; all the dark and twisted offspring of the un-living N'kroi. They roamed across the face of the world, awaiting the judgement of the Most High Lord of the Mountain.

Then came the humans. Deceived by the N'kroi, they left their home upon the mount. Lost in a world of darkness, they await the promised Son of the Mountain who will show them the path of return. But as they wait, they must survive. Cut off from their creator, surrounded by countless foes, they must slash and hack a place for themselves in which to live.

User summary:
ARG: The Adventure Role Play Gaming System is published as a series of eight major HTML pages, including: ARG Index, Introduction, Author's Forward, Creating Characters, Skills, Magery, Combat, and Wounds and Healing. The system is intended to be a generic/universal RPG system but to date has been implemented only within a fantasy milieu. Nearly all opposed actions in the game, except combat, are resolved through the skill system which is well-developed. The skill score plus d20 roll is compared against a target difficulty to determine outcome. Skill ratings increase through use. Combat is handled through a fairly traditional system of rounds, hits, and damage.

184105.name: The World of Anghar
rpg: ARG: The Adventure Role Play Gaming System
184105.description:
From the Cosmology:

The World of Anghar exists in a system of eight planets. Each of Anghar's neighbors corresponds with one of the Seven Spheres of Magery and is viewed by the inhabitants as being the seat or throne of one of the Seven Servants.

User Summary:

The World of Anghar is a complex, unique setting developed specifically for use with ARG: The Adventure Role Play Gaming System though it could be used with nearly any fantasy system. The setting is available freely and consists of ten major HTML pages, including: WOA Index, World of Anghar, Anghar's History, The Hierarchy, Dragons, The Eight Races, The Demi-Humans, The Dark Races, Neebo's Landing, and Miscellaneous (Slavery, Money).

The Eight Races include Aishen, Hrtryn, Rahidyn, Ruakyn, T'howmin, Tlassi, Tzorvyn, and Voshin. The Demi-Humans include Mann, Booka, Duergar, and Faeyn. Each species is thoughtfully linked to an audio file that gives the correct pronunciation of the species name.

Neebo's Landing is a large market town and is developed fully, with maps, keyed locations, and NPCs. Most campaigns are apparently intended to originate (and be based) here.

184108.name: Monopoly: Despicable Me 2
184108.description:
It's the classic fast-dealing property trading game of Monopoly, now with multitudes of minions! Gru is back with another evil plan and it's up to you to collect Banana Bucks and own all of your favorite properties before he succeeds. Spin the Minion Spinner to move your minion around the board and wheel and deal to win the most mischievous Monopoly game ever!

This Despicable Me 2 version of Monopoly is mischievous property-trading fun! Buy and sell properties! Collect Banana Bucks! Includes exclusive minions! 50 minions to collect! (Each sold separately.)

Game includes 4 minion tokens, spinner pod with Nom Nom Tom minion, game track, game tray (plus 2 clips), 16 Cupcake tokens, 8 Ice-Cream Sundae tokens, 16 Property cards, 16 Chance cards, Banana Bucks and game guide.

184109.name: ARPLE: All-purpose Role Playing Logistics Engine
rpg: ARPLE: All-purpose Role Playing Logistics Engine
184109.description:
User summary:

ARPLE: All-purpose Role Playing Logistics Engine is made freely accessible on the web as a series of documents which can be viewed either as HTML or downloaded in Wordperfect (.WPD), Rich Text Format (.RTF), or Word (.DOC) format.

The ARPLE system is an attempt to create a universal mechanic that can be utilized in any genre by players at any experience level. The introduction states "ARPLE is not, however, a revolution in roleplaying games. Rather, it is a return to the basics...". Even though a generic and universal system was a principle design goal, the system is clearly set in a fantasy milieu.

The system does use d6, d8, and d10, but the d6 is nearly exclusively used (and can be exclusively used).

184112.name: The Long Dark
videogamehonor: 2014 CVA Best Downloadable Game of the Year Nominee
2014 CVA Best Game Design of the Year Nominee
2014 CVA Best Game Innovation of the Year Nominee
2014 CVA Best Indie Game of the Year Nominee
2014 CVA Best Visual Arts of the Year Nominee
2014 Global Game Awards Best Early Access Game of the Year Nominee
2015 Game Developers Choice Awards Best New IP of the Year Honorable Mention
184112.description:
UNRELEASED GAME – AVAILABLE




This game is still either in Early-Alpha or Beta (or any status in between) but IS already available for sale / early access, so CAN BE PLAYED.




User Summary

Try to survive the harsh Canadian winter.

184113.name: Attack of the Mutant Rules System
rpg: Attack of the Mutant Rules System
184113.description:
User summary:

Attack of the Mutant Rules System is heavily influenced by the Amber Diceless RPG, but is focused exclusively on superhero action. Character creation uses a "point buy" system that allows players to allocate (usually) 50 points among attributes, pseudo-attributes (if any), and powers. Negative score can be allocated to attributes to boost something else (for example, a -20 score could be taken in strength so that 70 points would then be available). Attributes range from -30 to +100.

Pseudo-attributes include things such as appearance, wealth, perception, and luck. Pseudo-attributes range from -5 to +10.

Powers are purchased for one point, when they are considered latent and undeveloped. They can then be increased by purchase or through play.

184114.name: Multiplay
184114.description:
Multiplay is a "multiplication learning game of luck and skill." It is played on a board numbered from 2 to 9 across the top and along one side, forming a grid. Chips showing all the multiplication products of the numbers on the grid are included. Each player takes an equal number of chips from a face-down pile and places them standing on edge, so they are visible to the owning player and hidden from other players. Leftover chips are placed on the correct squares of the board.

In turn, each player spins a spinner, looks at his or her chips, and places any chips corresponding to the number spun onto the grid. If the chip is placed incorrectly (i.e. not the product of the numbers in the row and column) the player must take the chip back and lose a turn. If the spinning player does not have the number spun, he passes to the player on his left, who may then play that number if possible. If not, play continues to pass to the left until a player can play the number. If no one has the chip, the first player to spin spins again until someone can play a number.

The first player to play all his or her tiles wins.

184115.name: Random AMRS: The Pseudo-Diceless Roleplaying System
rpg: Attack of the Mutant Rules System
184115.description:
User summary:

This document provides variant rules for using dice to randomize combat in the Attack of the Mutant Rules System (which otherwise is a diceless system).

The system uses two six-sided dice, summed (2d6) to roll against a target number determined by the GM. Note that no modifiers of any kind are used - the GM compares a suitable skill or power to a situational difficulty and determines the target number (2-12) which the player must achieve or exceed.

184116.name: IDK:  I Don't Know - The Role-Playing Game
rpg: IDK:  I Don't Know - The Role-Playing Game
184116.description:
IDK: I Don't Know - The Role-Playing Game was developed to be a simple system suited to single-night play, though it could be used in a more-traditional campaign setting. The rules allow an adventure that can be designed and run with little preparation.

Players allocate 400 percentage points among twelve skills (Combat, Remain Calm, Persuasion, Notice, React Fast, Skulk, Transport, Cogitate, Education, Endure Suffering, Athletics, and Enigma). Specialties may be selected, and they have an impact on skills. Players may not allocate more than 65% into any one skill and should take less than 25% in any skill only with caution. Skill checks are made by rolling percentile dice and rolling under the character's score in the appropriate skill.

184117.description:
ManaSurge is a competitive magical card game in which dueling wizards fight for possession of the mystical World Crystal, a valued relic among magic users that grants immense power to whichever wizard wields it. You are one of the many wizards who have come to claim the stone, but gaining control of the stone won’t be an easy task.

This free-for-all magical showdown pits 2-6 wizards against each other over a series of rounds. Each round is a magical duel between all the wizards, which includes six different types of magic: Blades, Fireball, Frost Wave, Lightning, Quake and Metamagic. These magic types will aid wizards in their duel.

Players take turns casting an initial spell that will set the rule for the round, set the rank other players must beat, and earn them a potential Shard (VP). Players then take turns playing cards of equal or higher rank from their hands to the table; if they match the spell suit, they place a Shard on that card. The round ends when a player can no longer play a valid card from their hand. The player that could not play a card returns any Shards on their played cards back to the center, then takes card damage equal to the amount of Shards that are still on cards. All other players then take the Shards on cards they played to their Victory Pool. The player who played the last card gets a bonus Shard.

When a player takes damage, they draw cards from the deck equal to the amount of damage and place them face down in front of them. If they ever accumulate 5+ damage, they immediately discard their hand and a Shard, then take their damage cards in to their hand.

The game ends when one player has enough Shards. 15 in a two-player game, 12 for three or four players, and 10 for five or six.
184117.name: ManaSurge
boardgamepodcastepisode: Episode 21: Steam Works And Duel Lists
The Rebellion

184118.name: The Damp Man
184118.description:
The Damp Man (subtitled Swim Meet of Doom!) is s concise adventure for Call of Cthulhu. The adventure is adapted from the story "The Damp Man" by Allison V. Harding. It was originally published in the Chaosium Digest (periodical e-mail digest). The adventure is set in the modern time period but can also be readily adapted to the 1920s.

The adventure begins with the investigators attending a local girls' swimming competition in the early qualifications for the state swimming championships.

184119.name: The Deeper Dream
184119.description:
User summary:

Players in The Deeper Dream generate eight attributes (Will, Imagination, Innate Power, Solidity, Strength, Toughness, Balance, and Aim) using 3d6 for each each. Players then distribute 100 percentage points among one to four skills (taking fewer than four skills allows for faster future progression). Most skills are Dreamworld skills, but some are used in the Waking World. To determine success in opposed actions, percentage dice are rolled and compared to the appropriate skill statistic. If no skill applies, a d20 roll may instead be called for to be made against a suitable attribute. In both cases, the die roll must be lower than the skill or attribute to achieve success.

One unique aspect of the game concerns death, which is rarely permanent in dreams. Instead, characters may lose the ability to dream for several days or suffer other negative effects.

184120.name: Little Dungeon: Maximus
184120.description:
Seek adventure, loot the dungeon, and maybe fight a dinosaur or defeat an ancient king. Choose to be a wizard, rogue, barbarian or a knight. Work with your fellow adventurers or choose to win at any costs.

Little Dungeon: Maximus is the highly anticipated second entry into the Little Dungeon tabletop universe. This expansion adds: player roles, abilities, new bosses, new monsters weapons, armor, relic loot, traps, and rule updates and enhancements.

184121.name: Owzat T20 Cricket
184121.description:
From the company web site...
Since its inception in 2003 Twenty/20 cricket has gained in popularity making it an important part of the modern game, batting, bowling & fielding techniques have become more evident in the longer versions of the game as more & more T20 games are played year on year.

Twenty20 cricket is currently the shortest version of the game with scores in excess of 200 possible on the (mainly) batsman friendly wickets used for this format of the game.

Twenty20 cricket emulates to reproduce the excitement & tension that draws such big crowds to the real thing, within this game are four batting grids for different types of wickets. Along with four batting & four bowling grades plus a few other charts that will enable the user to replay a full game in around 30-45 minutes when the rules have been mastered, this will ensure a statistically accurate scorecard with a wealth of stats (strike rates, economy rates etc.) and hopefully a nail-biting finish to boot.

Rating players is a simple task & although the grades are in themselves quite basic they will reproduce roughly what is achieved in real life (a T20 batsman's strike rate is regarded as a more valuable asset than his average and a bowlers economy is his main ˜weapon").

The game includes the following Ratings:

ICC World T20 (2014)

Friends Life domestic T20 (2013).

Big Bash league 2013-14

Indian Premier League 2014

Champions League 2013

Caribbean Premier League 2013

The game is played mainly with 2d6 and a d10, which is used occasionally. Batters score runs by rolling a die and moving up a grid, different ones are based on the condition of the wicket. Their starting point on the grid is based on their letter grade. Certain points of the grid will then reference the bowler's grade - you roll a d10 to determine if the batter is out or not.

184122.name: Castle Builder
184122.description:
Castle Builder is a card drafting game where the cards you select build a castle that will house Nobles, Knights, Servants, Princesses and even a King and Queen! There are 3 rounds of drafting where the cards get more valuable, but more expensive and your gold is dwindling. Fortunately each card you add to your castle has 3 attributes, Victory Points for winning, Defense to protect against other players attacks and Favor. Favor is added to your Victory Points at the end of the game, but in between rounds it can be traded in for more gold so you can afford the more expensive cards, but then gold is not worth any Victory Points. There are other ways to gain gold such as sending your knights on adventures or buying Vaults for the Nobles to store their wealth in.

Speaking of Nobles and Knights these can be added to your castle through adding specific cards and score addition points at the end of the game. The real prize is when you add the right rooms to gain the King or Queen!

However, your opponents will be attempting to ruin your prospects of success. They can pay to discard cards you need, throw waste into your castle preventing people from inhabiting it or just outright attacking you to steal Victory Points.

It is up to you to manage your gold, Nobles, Knights and Servants to build the most impressive castle and win the game!

184124.name: 9.03m
184124.description:
User Summary

9.03m is an art/empathy game that aims to humanise, and remember the victims of the 2011 Japanese tsunami.

184125.name: The Moon Sliver
184125.description:
User Summary

You are on an island and you seem to be alone, but fires and candles still burn. A story of guilt, loneliness, and faith is revealed.

184126.name: Ultraworld
184126.description:
User Summary

Explore a vibrant world where the landscape itself is a living painting.

184127.name: Verde Station
184127.description:
User Summary

What do you trust most: what you see, what you're told, or your instincts? Aboard Verde Station, you will test your wits and question everything.

184128.name: The Lost Valley
184128.description:
User Summary

You play as a cyclist who gets into an accident. The bicycle is broken as a result of cliff falling and the protagonist has to move further on foot.

184129.name: Home is Where One Starts...
videogamehonor: 2016 Emotional Games Best Vr Game Nominee
184129.description:
User Summary

A story about childhood, hope, and the miracle of memory. You play as a little girl from a broken home somewhere in the American South.

184130.name: Dream
184130.description:
User Summary

Dream is an exploration game that takes place within the subconscious mind of Howard Phillips, a young man whose waking hours are tedious and dull.

184131.name: Corpse of Discovery
184131.description:
User Summary

Corpse of Discovery is an exploration game located on a myriad of planetary landscapes.

184132.name: Tonight You Die
184132.description:
wander a dreary city of concrete structures and unknown melodies

tonight you die is an audio rich first person exploration game. players are abandoned in a desolate brutalist cityscape with only a menacing note as a clue: "tonight you die"

Source: The Game Website.

184134.name: Aurea
184134.description:
Aurea - A Role-playing System

User summary:

Aurea is intended to be a generic, universal role-playing system. Characters have twelve attributes (Strength, Dexterity, Constitution, Physical Speed, Size, Comeliness, Reaction Speed, Willpower, Intelligence, Mental Fitness, Mental Speed, and Learning) that range from 3-12 each. Alternately, characters can be generated with a 120 point buy. Characters then have points distributed from a pool to various skills, ranging from zero to seven (basic competency) and increasing to 18 and beyond. Skills increase in score by repetitive successful use. Skill success and combat are resolved according to a resolution table that maps difficulty class against skill level on a resolution table, yielding a percentage. Characters then roll percentile dice and attempt to roll under the table number.

Even though the system is intended to be generic, all weapons and armor listed are for traditional fantasy equipment, and an appendix is given for magic and psionics systems. A final index offers numerous optional rules that replace the standard rules.

From the introduction:

Aurea is a generic system, which means that it should be applicable to every possible world-setting. It has been used in a variety of medieval fantasy worlds, a realistic medieval world, in a cyberpunk setting, two classical era settings, in the China of Judge Dee, in a Cthulhu-like setting and a couple more.

184135.name: Shʌpe of the World
184135.description:
Shape of the World is an ephemeral first-person exploration game where the world grows around you in a procedurally populated environment. Exploration is about intentionally getting lost and the joy of being found again. Your presence is the driving force behind the evolving environment as you establish permanent monuments to mark your way. Without your presence, will the forest still come alive?

Source: The Game Website.

184136.name: Ruah
184136.description:
User Summary

Ruah is a beautiful low poly first person exploration game. You explore a strange island inhabited by magical deer.

184137.name: Astæria
184137.description:
User Summary

Astaeria is a first-person exploration game where poems power the world generator. Feed it a poem, like the ones packaged within, and it will give you a vibrant world of color and procedurally arranged music.

Source: The Game Website.

184138.name: Aurora: Quick-Start Guide
184138.description:
User summary:

The Aurora: Quick-Start Guide (60 pages) was distributed with four supplemental PDF files, namely: Combat Flow Chart (1 page), Encounter Sheet (1 page), Equipment and Weapons List (6 pages), and Weapons Chart (3 pages).

The Aurora: Quick-Start Guide, distributed for free, presented a complete rule set that was scaled down from the full release which was sold commercially. The game was a fairly traditional "hard" science fiction role-playing game that used the novel "Push Dice System" where players were assumed to succeed unless they rolled a failure. The system allowed the players to select how many dice to roll in a pool but each additional dice carried a potential failure. Managing dice pools was therefore of major significance during play.

184139.name: Character Sheet Set
184139.description:
User summary:

In the Aurora system character race significantly influenced character development, both in providing unique opportunities and real restrictions. As each race resulted in a unique character build process the system provided separate character sheets for each race, keyed to that race's developmental potentials.

The character sheet set was distributed as seven one-page documents, including separate sheets for each race, namely: A'wahch, Uhrmina, Human, Jeotsu (female), Jeotsu (male), Xor-Nast, and Milrolk.

184140.name: Aurora Almanac
184140.description:
User summary:

The Aurora Almanac was provided as five separate files, four of which contained details on specific star systems, namely: The Hrn'glak'r System (8 pages), The Kalunz System (18 pages), The Tarizik System (14 pages), and the Unajralo System (10 pages). Each of these supplements details a named system and environs. The fifth document, Turoru-Based Jump-Capable Ships (28 pages), enumerates twenty-three spaceships for use in the game.

184141.name: Childbirth Trivia
184141.description:
Childbirth Trivia is a trivia game to test and teach knowledge about childbirth to expectant parents or health professionals. Players compete to answer questions in a number of categories. Players roll a die to determine which of six categories they will answer. Another player draws a card of the corresponding color and asks the question. If the question is answered correctly, the player rolls again and answers another question, continuing until an answer is wrong. Once a player answers questions in all six categories, he or she must answer one last question in a category chosen by the other players. A correct answer wins the game.

A longer version of the game requires players to progress through various levels. Some levels require answers in each category, some are free choice categories and others allow opponents to choose the categories.

Questions may be asked at level 1 (for the general public or expectant parents) or level 2, for health professionals or other childbirth professionals.

This game can also be played with a board from Trivial Pursuit or a similar game, substituting the Childbirth Trivia cards.

184143.name: The BDGRP FREE COPY
rpg: The Beer Drinkers Guide to Role-Playing
184143.description:
From the Introduction:

Welcome to the Beer Drinkers Guide to Role Playing. "FREE WORLD" This is a pen and paper Role Playing Game (RPG) designed to be easy and fun to play. Yes it’s a little dated however, in this age of technology maybe you want to take a break and unplug. If you are familiar with Role Playing games you shouldn’t see anything within these pages that is too hard to digest. If you are a virgin (never played Role Playing Games before). I believe you will find the rules are written in a very simple manner or layman's terms "easy to understand and straight forward." Please remember this is a fictional future of our world and broad assumptions are taken on the world's direction, nothing is meant to be offensive, everything is nothing more than speculative fictional satire. I do sincerely hope you enjoy this game, thanks in advance I Don't Know Jack.

184144.name: Chocolate Shop Frenzy
184144.description:
User Summary

First of the "... Shop Frenzy"-games, where you manage your chocolat shop by tending to customers, getting their orders swift & correct, upgrading your shop and playing some abstract mini-game(s) in between which has the chocolate items theme slapped on.

184145.description:
Flash Duel: Second Edition is a simple, fast card game that simulates sparring matches amongst Fantasy Strike characters. The fight takes place on an 18-space linear track, and it's all about striking from the right distance and getting to the right range. This edition contains 20 characters, each with their own special abilities, allowing for hundreds of different matchups.

There are seven different modes of play:

Simple mode, for first time players
Full mode, using the character abilities
Custom Clockwork: build your own character!
2v2 team battle
Solo play, with 10 achievements to earn
Raid on Deathstrike Dragon: 2, 3, or 4 players cooperate against a powerful 5th player controlling the Dragon
Betrayal at Raid on Deathstrike Dragon: A more difficult raid where one player is secretly on the Dragon's side!




Changes to the Revised Second Edition:

--All game modes now use a 40 card deck, rather than different modes using 25, 40, and 50, and the game will come with 40 numbered cards rather than 50. In all modes other than the Dragon Raid, you start each round by shuffling the deck and setting aside 5 cards without looking at them. In 2v2, you reshuffle the discard pile twice when it runs out before reaching timout. In the Dragon Raid, you reshuffle it 1, 2, and 3 times for 2, 3, and 4 morals, respectively. Overall, rounds last longer in all modes.

--Last-hits is no longer a mechanic in the game. At timeout, you just check who advanced farthest. This is simpler and turns out to have better dynamics by forcing action to take place during the actual gameplay part of the game.

--Whenever a round ends in a tie, now both sides get a win token.

--A new rulebook makes the game less mathy and more about improv and bluffing. Players don't know the exact contents of the deck anymore, so they can't compute things so completely. Also, players now draw more cards each round, so they have more chance to win before timeout.

Part of the Fantasy Strike universe.
184145.name: Flash Duel: Revised Second Edition

184146.description:
Rube Goldberg is a promotional character for Steampunk Rally, offered initially as a print-and-play option and included in the Tesla Editions; however, he is available for purchase, and could be included in an expansion later. Rather than having the standard two cards, a cockpit and a machine, Rube has a single 4×4 card depicting an understandably simplified take on a Rube Goldberg device. Through the depicted convoluted series of mechanisms, a fire die provides a single activation (★) of 1 movement!

The print-and-play PDF also includes the inventor stand (the playing piece for the racecourse) in two sizes: one to match the size of those in the retail/Kickstarter version of the game, and another to match the size of those in the print-and-play version of the game.
184146.name: Steampunk Rally: Rube Goldberg
boardgamefamily: Games by the Game Artisans of Canada

184147.name: Sanctuary
184147.description:
Walk and enjoy the scenery.

Source: The Game Website.

184148.name: Gardenarium
184148.description:
Gardenarium is a chill adventure taking place on a cloud in the sky. You land as a stranger and struggle to gain access to the mysterious Depot by picking up trash and making the land grow.

Source: The Game Website.

184149.name: Im Null
184149.description:
On one side was this chat log of rushed exclamation, while the other housed a screen in black with a small window at its center, which let me peer into the wireframe void world of im null.

Source: The Game Website.

184151.name: Legend of the Five Rings: The Card Game
boardgamepodcastepisode: Strange Assembly 206 - Seven Factions
184151.description:
Description from the publisher:

Welcome to the realm of Rokugan: a land of samurai and mystics, mad dragons and divine beings — a land where honor is stronger than steel. Here, the clans serve the Emperor and engage in courtly deceptions and power plays, even as they wage war against each other and the evil forces that plague their realm. This is the world of Legend of the Five Rings!
